facts.text: Writ Petition No. 84 of 1958 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 84 of 1958. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights, C. Mathur, for the petitioners. K. Daphtary, Solicitor-General of India, B. Sen, R. H. Dhebar and T. M. Sen, for the respondent. 1961. 1961. April 20.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 20, 1961 by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-This is a petition filed under Ga. Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging the validity of the excise tariff imposed by el.  6  in entry 4 1  in the First Schedule to the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944  1 of 1944 .

facts.text: Petitioners Nos. 1 to 17 are tobacco cultivators who grow and sell tobacco in Kaimganj Tahsil, District of Farrukhabad, Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Petitioners Nos. 1 to 17 are tobacco cultivators and they carry on the trade and business of growing tobacco and of selling it in Kaimganj Tahsil in the District of Farrukhabad in Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Petitioners 18 to 30 are partners, proprietors or agents of firms which are private bonded warehouse licensees purchasing tobacco from cultivators and selling to dealers or other private warehouse licensees.

anchor.surface_text: Petitioners 18 to 30 are partners or proprietors or agents of firms which are private bonded warehouse licensees and they carry on trade and business of purchasing tobacco from the cultivators and of selling the same to dealers or to other private warehouse licensees.

facts.text: Petition seeks writ of mandamus restraining Union of India from levying excise duty on hooka and chewing tobacco under clause 6 in entry 41 First Schedule to Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: By their petition the petitioners have asked for a writ, direction or order in the nature of mandamus to be issued to the respondent, the Union of India, restraining it from levying excise duty on hooka and chewing tobacco under the impugned item and any other writ, direction or order which may be found suitable to protect the fundamental rights of the petitioners to carry on their trade and business of dealing in hooka and chewing tobacco.

facts.text: Challenge to validity of excise tariff imposed by cl. 6 in entry 41 First Schedule to Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-This is a petition filed under Ga. Art. 32 of the Constitution challenging the validity of the excise tariff imposed by el.  6  in entry 4 1  in the First Schedule to the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944  1 of 1944 .

facts.text: Petitioners concede they cannot substantiate that rates are excessive and destroy trade.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mathur, for the petitioners, fairly companyceded that he would number be able to substantiate the first ground of challenge, and indeed it is obvious that a challenge to tax law on the mere ground that the tariff imposed by the tax law is heavy cannot be enter- tained.

facts.text: Challenge based on unconstitutional discrimination under Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: That leaves the question of discrimination alone to be companysidered in the present petition. For the purpose of this petition we will assume that if discrimination in respect of companysodities taxed is proved it ultimately amounts to a discrimination against the persons taxed and therefore Art. 14 can be invoked in such a case.

facts.text: Entry 4 in First Schedule deals with tobacco, defining it as any form cured or uncured, manufactured or not, including leaf, stalks, stems, but not attached to earth.

anchor.surface_text: The tariff entry in dispute as it number obtains under the taxing statute is entry 4 in the First Schedule. It deals with tobacco. Under this entry tobacco means any form of tobacco, whether cured or uncured and whether manufactured or number, and includes the leaf, stalks and stems of the tobacco plant, but does number include any part of a tobacco plant while still attached to the earth.

facts.text: Clause 6 under item 5 in entry 4 prescribes tariff of Rs. 2.20 nP. per kilogram for tobacco other than flue cured and not otherwise specified.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  6  in this item with which we are companycerned in the present petition deals with tobacco other than flue cured and number otherwise specified. For this residuary clause the tariff prescribed is Rs. 2.20 nP. per kilogram. This tariff is double the tariff prescribed for the classes in the preceding item.

facts.text: Tariff for item 5 clause 4 is Rs. 1.10 nP. per kilogram.

anchor.surface_text: For tobacco falling under the four clauses under item  5  the tariff is Rs. 1.10nP. per kilogram.

facts.text: Petitioners' tobacco cannot be distinguished rationally from tobacco covered by item 5 cl. 4, so double tariff is discriminatory.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mathurs grievance is that the tobacco with which the petitioners deal cannot-be distinguished on any rational basis from the tobacco companyered by item  5 , cl.  4 , and so the imposition of a double tariff on the tobacco in which the petitioners deal is invalid inasmuch as it is based on unconstitutional discrimination.

facts.text: Tariff prescribed not primarily by reference to use but based on Tobacco Expert Committee recommendations.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with. this argument it would be relevant very briefly to refer to the report of the Tobacco Expert Committee whose recommendations have furnished the main basis for the present revised tariff in respect of tobacco.

facts.text: Tobacco Expert Committee report indicates tariff framed so incidence falls equitably on all classes using tobacco.

anchor.surface_text: Tobacco, as the Committees report points out, is a rich mans solace and a poor mans companyfort. Since it is used by all classes of people in various forms it is necessary to frame the tariff in such a way that the incidence of tax shall fall equitably on all classes of people using it.

facts.text: Previous Intention Tariff ineffective due to evasion; substituted by flat rate, then capability tariff.

anchor.surface_text: The report then points out that the Intention Tariff based on the principle of intention was found to be, ineffective because the assessees declaration of intended use left large room for evasion of tax. That is why the Intention Tariff was substituted by a flat rate of duty. By experience it was found that even this method was number very effective or equitable and then was adopted the capability tariff.

facts.text: Taxation Enquiry Committee 1953 recommended classifying tobacco by standards identifiable visually or by simple tests for capability in biris.

anchor.surface_text: The report has examined the advantages of the capability tariff and has quoted the opinion of the Taxation Enquiry Committee which made its report in 1953. The report companysidered the volume of evidence adduced before it and took into account all the suggestions made. In view of the practical difficulties brought before us, says the report, we companysider that, within the present tariff, the only workable and satisfactory method of classifying tobacco will be to prescribe standards readily identifiable either visually or by other simple tests and manipulations with a view to determine empirically what is capable and what is incapable of use in biris.

facts.text: Committee concluded criterion is physical form affecting suitability for biri making.

anchor.surface_text: The companyclusion of the Committee, therefore, was that the only criterion which is safe to adopt is the one relating to the physical form of tobacco as affecting its suitability for biri making.

facts.text: Whole leaf form tobacco cured by moisture harder to convert to flakes for biris, higher crumble.

anchor.surface_text: Tobacco cured in whole leaf form cannot be companyverted into flakes as readily as tobacco cured by dry curing methods, and in the opinion of the Committee, although it is possible to prepare flakes out of tobacco cured in whole leaf form the process of companyversion into flakes causes much higher proportions to crumble into dust, raw and other unsalable forms.

facts.text: Broken leaf grades liable to higher rate but can be converted to rawa or dust for lower rate.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the broken leaf grades which the Committee recommended should be liable to assessment at the higher rate relief was recommended by permitting any owner to companyvert his broken leaf tobacco into fine rawa or dust in which form it will become physically unusable for biris.

facts.text: Distinction between cl.5 and cl.6 based on physical form and capability, reasonable for tariff object.

anchor.surface_text: By the test of physical form the two articles are different. By the test of capability of user they are different and in a sense according to the Committees recommendations they partake of the character of different companysodities.

facts.text: Court holds attack on validity on ground of discrimination cannot be upheld.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, the distinction between tobacco falling under cl.  5  and cl.  6 , according to the report of the Committee, is so clear and unambiguous and its relation to the object intended by the imposition of tariff is so clearly reasonable that the attack against its validity on the ground of unconstitutional discrimination cannot be upheld.

facts.text: Petitioners claim Nicotiana Rustica used exclusively for hooka and chewing in Uttar Pradesh, unfit for biris or cigarettes.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mathur companytended that Nicotiana Rustica with which the petitioners deal is used exclusively for hooka and chewing in Uttar Pradesh. The petition avers that the variety of Nicotiana Rustica which is used in biris is number grown in Uttar Pradesh and that all the tobacco which is grown in Kaimganj is Nicotiana Rustica which is either pit cured or ground cured.

facts.text: Counter-affidavit denies exclusive use of Nicotiana Rustica for non-biri purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the fact that the question as to whether the particular tobacco in which the petitioners deal falls under the impugned clause or number cannot be legitimately raised in a, petition under Art. 32, the answer to the plea is furnished by the companynter-affidavit and the report of the Committee.

facts.text: Committee states Rustica broken leaf grades can be used in biris with admixture.

anchor.surface_text: In the companynter-affidavit the allegations made in regard to the exalusive user of Nicotiana Rustica are generally denied, and what is more the report of the Committee specifically points out that though Rustica varieties of tobacco are generally number known to be used for biris, when they are cured in broken leaf grades they can be used with admixture with biri tobacco like Pandharpuri tobacco for imparting strength to biri mixtures.

facts.text: Petitioners' tobacco grievance that it can never be used for biris is not well founded.

anchor.surface_text: Besides, it would be quite possible for dealers in the said varieties of tobacco to send them to other parts of the companyntry where they are used for the purpose of manufacturing biris. Therefore, the grievance made by the petitioners that the tobacco in which they deal can never be used for biris is obviously number well founded.

issues.text: Whether a challenge to tax law on the mere ground that the tariff imposed by the tax law is heavy can be entertained

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mathur, for the petitioners, fairly conceded that he would not be able to substantiate the first ground of challenge, and indeed it is obvious that a challenge to tax law on the mere ground that the tariff imposed by the tax law is heavy cannot be entertained.

issues.text: Whether discrimination in respect of commodities taxed amounts to a discrimination against the persons taxed such that Article 14 can be invoked

anchor.surface_text: That leaves the question of discrimination alone to be considered in the present petition. For the purpose of this petition we will assume that if discrimination in respect of commodities taxed is proved it ultimately amounts to a discrimination against the persons taxed and therefore Art. 14 can be invoked in such a case.

issues.text: Whether the tobacco with which the petitioners deal cannot be distinguished on any rational basis from the tobacco covered by item 5, cl. 4, making the imposition of a double tariff invalid as unconstitutional discrimination

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mathurs grievance is that the tobacco with which the petitioners deal cannot-be distinguished on any rational basis from the tobacco covered by item  5 , cl.  4 , and so the imposition of a double tariff on the tobacco in which the petitioners deal is invalid inasmuch as it is based on unconstitutional discrimination.

arguments.claim: Tariff classification based on Tobacco Expert Committee report distinguishing by physical form and capability for biri use, reasonable and non-discriminatory for equitable tax incidence

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with this argument it would be relevant very briefly to refer to the report of the Tobacco Expert Committee whose recommendations have furnished the main basis for the present revised tariff in respect of tobacco. In substance this report shows that the present tariff cannot be said to have been prescribed either wholly or even primarily by reference actually to the use of tobacco.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mathur, for the petitioners, fairly conceded that he would not be able to substantiate the first ground of challenge, and indeed it is obvious that a challenge to tax law on the mere ground that the tariff imposed by the tax law is heavy cannot be entertained.

Therefore, in our opinion, the distinction between tobacco falling under cl. 5 and cl. 6 , according to the report of the Committee, is so clear and unambiguous and its relation to the object intended by the imposition of tariff is so clearly reasonable that the attack against its validity on the ground of unconstitutional discrimination cannot be upheld.
